s.text: "A mature woman is married to a man who is a perpetual adolescent; he is clever and good with words, but lacks a sense of self-worth, and relieves his depression with recurrent affairs of varying importance."

But in an editorial, the Sun said he should not be fired because "he performed well over the bombing of Iraq and has built up a solid relationship with his American opposite number Madeleine Albright."

"A mature woman is married to a man who is a perpetual adolescent; he is clever and good with words, but lacks a sense of self-worth, and relieves his depression with recurrent affairs of varying importance."

"A mature woman is married to a man who is a perpetual adolescent; he is clever and good with words, but lacks a sense of self-worth, and relieves his depression with recurrent affairs of varying importance."
He added, "Nobody knows how the crisis may have affected their marriage: but those who know the first lady well know that she is a woman of great strength, with very broad shoulders."
"Cast both stories as novels, and ask what is the core of the plot," he wrote.
